column1: Walnut is a city in the eastern part of Los Angeles County in the U.S. state of California. Money's Best Places to Live ranked Walnut #70 in 2009 and #57 in 2011
column2: the highest ranking for a California city in both years. As of the 2010 census
column3: the city had a population of 29

column6: 685.The greater Walnut Valley is located between the steep San Jose Hills mountain range to the north
column7: and the gentle Puente Hills to the south. Quality housing consists of master-planned single family homes ranging in size from 1
column10: 040 m2). The city hosts a highly ranked public school system—the Walnut Valley Unified School District
column11: which has been ranked by numerous sources as one of the top public school districts in Southern California as well as Mt. San Antonio College. Walnut is one of the cities with the lowest crime rates in the San Gabriel Valley.The city covers nearly 9 square miles (23 km2) and is home to hundreds of businesses. column13: 250.The city's name is derived from the Rancho Los Nogales Mexican land grant
column14: nogales being the Spanish word for "walnut trees". The native California black walnut is a common tree of the San Jose Hills. The City of Walnut is a general law city incorporated on January 19
column15: 1959. It is governed by a city council/city manager form of government. A five-member city council is elected by the residents
column16: and a mayor is elected annually by the council to serve a twelve-month term. A city manager is appointed by the council to oversee the daily activities of the city.

column1: Walnut is located on the southern slopes of the San Jose Hills

column1: The history of Walnut dates back to the indigenous Tongva people. Spanish missionaries who arrived in the 18th century called the indigenes Gabrieleño
column2: because the area where they lived was controlled by the San Gabriel Mission. The Walnut area was part of the network of outlying ranches used for the grazing of cattle and sheep by the Mission.

column1: Following secularization of the missions in the 1830s
column2: former mission lands were divided into ranchos
column3: and given away as land grants by the Mexican government of Alta California. In the Walnut area
column4: the first grants were Rancho San Jose (granted to Ricardo Vejar and Ygnacio Palomares in 1837); Rancho Los Nogales (granted to Jose De La Cruz Linares in 1840); and Rancho La Puente (granted to John Rowland and William Workman in 1842). In 1868
column5: John Rowland and William Workman divided Rancho La Puente
column6: leaving Rowland the eastern half and Workman the western half. Rowland's land included the western portion of Walnut and the adjacent community now called Rowland Heights. The land was used mainly for raising cattle and growing wheat

column2: the first U.S. post office was established and given the name "Lemon". In 1908
column3: the post office name was changed to Walnut. As a reminder of those early days
column4: the U.S. Post Office is on Lemon Avenue
column5: one of the town's main streets.

column1: The City of Walnut's Bicentennial Commission selected the construction of Lemon Creek Park and the restoration of the William R. Rowland Adobe Redwood Ranch House as Walnut's bicentennial project. In 1872
column2: the Lemon Creek Park area became the property of Sheriff William Rowland
column3: who inherited the 29
column5: John Rowland. The modest structure built in 1883 served as the home of Mr. Meridith
column6: ranch foreman for William Rowland. The adobe redwood ranch house is one of the few remaining original ranch style redwood and adobe structures in the area. On October 1
column8: the State Landmark Committee placed the W.R. Rowland ranch house in the National Registry of Historical Places.

column1: Walnut is sometimes confused with the city of Walnut Creek in Northern California.
Walnut holds an annual Walnut Family Festival. On the day of festival
column2: several streets in the area (such as portions of Lemon and La Puente) are closed in the morning and a parade is held in which many local clubs and groups participate. Later in the afternoon
column3: a fair with booths
column6: and activities is held in Suzanne Park
column7: adjacent to Suzanne Middle School. The Walnut Family Festival usually occurs in early or mid-October.

column2: the Mt. SAC Relays are an annual track and field festival held primarily at Hilmer Lodge Stadium on the Mt. San Antonio College campus. The April festival attracts many elite athletes from around the world to the city of Walnut. This meet and other elite track meets held at the stadium
column3: including the 1968 Olympic Trials and two editions of the USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships have emblazoned the identification of "Walnut
column4: California" in numerous national records in athletics around the world. At various points in time
column5: many world records were set at the Mt. SAC Relays.

column1: The October Mt. SAC Cross Country Invitational
column2: run in the hills surrounding the stadium
column3: proclaims itself to be the largest Cross Country meeting in the world. Much of the same course is used as the annual CIF Southern Section championships and the western qualifier for the Foot Locker Cross Country Championships.
